unnormalised: In a recent update from the Delhi High Court, a civil law case involving property dispute between 2 brothers, Mr. Rohan Sharma and Mr. Vikas Sharma, has been adjourned till 15/11/2024. Adv. Mehra, representing Mr. Rohan Sharma, requested more time to present additional evidence relating to the land registry records from 2005.
normalised: In a recent update from the Delhi High Court, a civil law case involving property dispute between two brothers, Mister Rohan Sharma and Mister Vikas Sharma, has been adjourned till fifteenth november two thousand and twenty four. Advocate Mehra, representing Mister Rohan Sharma, requested more time to present additional evidence relating to the land registry records from two thousand and five.

unnormalised: The case, filed under Section 27 of the Specific Relief Act, revolves around a ancestral property located in Karol Bagh, Delhi. The dispute apparently began after their father's death in 2018. Mr. Vikas Sharma, represented by Adv. Banerjee, claims sole ownership based on a will that Mr. Rohan Sharma disputes as forged.
normalised: The case, filed under Section twenty seven of the Specific Relief Act, revolves around an ancestral property located in Karol Bagh, Delhi. The dispute apparently began after their father's death in two thousand and eighteen. Mister Vikas Sharma, represented by Advocate Banerjee, claims sole ownership based on a will that Mister Rohan Sharma disputes as forged.

unnormalised: "We are confident that the truth will prevail," Adv. Mehra stated outside the courtroom. "We have substantial evidence to prove that the will is not genuine and that Mr. Rohan is entitled to his rightful share of the property under Hindu Succession Act, 1956."
normalised: "We are confident that the truth will prevail," Advocate Mehra stated outside the courtroom. "We have substantial evidence to prove that the will is not genuine and that Mister Rohan is entitled to his rightful share of the property under Hindu Succession Act, one thousand nine hundred and fifty six."

unnormalised: Meanwhile, Adv. Banerjee asserted that their client has a strong case. "The will is legally sound and was duly registered. Mr. Vikas has been managing the property for several years now, and we are confident the court will rule in his favor." The next hearing is keenly anticipated by both parties.
normalised: Meanwhile, Advocate Banerjee asserted that their client has a strong case. "The will is legally sound and was duly registered. Mister Vikas has been managing the property for several years now, and we are confident the court will rule in his favor." The next hearing is keenly anticipated by both parties.

unnormalised: The case highlights the complexities often associated with property inheritance in India and serves as a reminder for folks to ensure proper documentation and registration of assets to avoid potential legal battles down the line. The cost to file such a civil case in Delhi can range anywhere from Rs. 5,000 to Rs. 25,000, depending on the valuation of the property being disputed.
